titlestmt.titleproper: Laurance S. Rockefeller papers, Correspondence Files
A Guide to the Laurance S. Rockefeller papers, Correspondence Files FA1283

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2020-10-22 05:38:37 -0400.

did.unittitle: Laurance S. Rockefeller papers, Correspondence Files

physdesc.extent: 71 document boxes, 1 oversized flat box, 1 oversized album case.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Open for research with select materials restricted as noted.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Laurance Spelman Rockefeller was born on May 26, 1910, in New York City, the fourth of the six children of Abby Aldrich and John D. Rockefeller, Jr. He attended the Lincoln School of Teachers College of Columbia University in New York before entering Princeton University in 1928. He graduated in 1932 with a B.A. degree in philosophy and went on to two years of graduate study at Harvard Law School.

On August 15, 1934, Laurance married Mary French in the Congregational Church in Woodstock, Vermont. Together they raised three daughters and a son. Laurance and Mary maintained homes in Manhattan and Pocantico Hills, New York; Jackson Hole, Wyoming; and Woodstock, Vermont.
During World War II, Laurance served in the U.S. Navy (1942-1945) in the Bureau of Aeronautics, attaining the rank of lieutenant commander.

Throughout his life, Laurance pursued a number of successful careers. He was a pioneer in the field of venture capital. He was an influential figure for three decades in the American conservation movement. He led the development of Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, one of the world's foremost cancer care and research facilities, and served as both a benefactor and advisor to major educational institutions. Laurance also combined his personal vision for conservation, recreation, and the spiritual needs of individuals to develop internationally acclaimed environmentally oriented resorts.

In 1935, he began working in the Family Office in Rockefeller Center. His first duties were to develop his knowledge of Rockefeller philanthropic activities, conservation projects, and business interests. Simultaneously, he developed his own interests, blending business acumen with the talents of a "gadgeteer," as he once referred to himself.

Laurance became well known as an investor of risk capital in young enterprises based primarily in scientific and technological development. Over the years his investment interests included the fields of aviation, aerospace, electronics, high temperature physics, composite materials, optics, lasers, data processing, thermionics, instrumentation, and nuclear power. Beginning in August 1969, his venture capital investments in these areas were made through Venrock, a venture capital group formed by members of the Rockefeller family. He also developed outstanding environmentally oriented resort hotels in Puerto Rico, the Virgin Islands, Hawaii, and Vermont, serving as the chair of Rockresorts, Inc., a resort management company that he founded.

Conservation of the environment and recreational development constituted much of Laurance's philanthropy and public service. His introduction to public service came in 1939, when Governor Herbert Lehman of New York appointed him to the Palisades Interstate Park Commission (PIPC). He later served as president of the PIPC from 1970 to 1977 and continued as a commissioner until his resignation in December 1978.

While on a family vacation in 1926, Laurance had visited the region of Wyoming that includes Grand Teton National Park. Captivated by the area, his father subsequently purchased a substantial amount of land around Jackson Hole to safeguard it and the view of the Grand Teton Mountains. In 1949, as president of Jackson Hole Preserve, Inc., Laurance made a gift to the federal government on behalf of his father of the valley land, which was included in Grand Teton National Park.

Laurance established the American Conservation Association, Inc., in 1958 as a philanthropy to function as a conservation service agency, assisting the work of other agencies—both private and governmental—and initiating projects of its own. It was part of the movement that helped to focus public attention on the quality of the American environment.

Also in 1958, President Dwight Eisenhower appointed him chair of the Outdoor Recreation Resources Review Commission, which charted ways to meet the nation's outdoor recreation needs through the end of the century. He was a special emissary for President Lyndon Johnson in the effort that led to the creation of the Redwood National Park in California, and he served as chair of President Richard Nixon's Citizens' Advisory Committee on Environmental Quality, successor to a similar group that he headed under President Johnson. He played a pivotal role in the creation and development of several national parks including Grand Teton National Park in Wyoming; Virgin Islands National Park on the island of St. John; and Marsh, Billings, Rockefeller National Historical Park in Vermont.

Laurance served as a leader of several important nonprofit and philanthropic organizations. He was president and later chair of the Rockefeller Brothers Fund (1958-1980) and was a trustee of the Alfred P. Sloan Foundation (1960-1982). His first association with Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center was in 1947; he also served as chair (1960-1982), overseeing an expansion and modernization of its operations. He was a longtime trustee of the New York Zoological Society (1935-1986) and served as its president (1969-1971) and chair (1971-1985).

Laurance received many honors for his efforts on behalf of the environment and cancer research and treatment. Among them are the Alfred P. Sloan, Jr. Memorial Award from the American Cancer Society (1969), the Medal of Freedom (1969), the Congressional Gold Medal (1991), and the Lady Bird Johnson Conservation Award for Lifetime Achievement (1997). In 2003, he became the first person to be made an honorary citizen of the British Virgin Islands in recognition of his many contributions to the area.
Laurance Rockefeller died on July 11, 2004, at his home on Fifth Avenue in Manhattan.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The LSR Correspondence Files collection is arranged into five series: Series 1 - Alphabetical; Series 2 - Friends and Associates; Series 3 - Mail Log; Series 4 - Chronological Files; Series 5 - Special Letters.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Correspondence Files collection of Laurance S. Rockefeller's papers, is comprised of alphabetical correspondence files for 1962-1991 from the LSR papers in the Rockefeller Family general files (record groups 3, 33, 37, and 39; and of LSR's files for individuals (Friends and Associates), pulled from these same general files. Sets of mail logs and chronological files, maintained by LSR's office from the early 1960s/early 1970s to around 1986, and two albums of "special letters" complete the collection.

While much of the correspondence is social in nature, the collection does help document LSR's personal and professional relationships, from longterm friends like Horace Albright to LSR's evolving interest in and support for spiritual ventures. The Friends and Associates series also partially documents LSR's working relationship with associates such as Clayton W. (Wes) Frye, Henry Diamond, and others.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Alphabetical Correspondence series contains LSR's personal correspondence files for the period 1962 - 1991, which originally formed part of LSR's papers in the Rockefeller Family general files, record groups 3, 33, 37, and 39. While there is much substantive correspondence in the files, a good portion of the materials consists of friendly notes and acknowledgment letters, social invitations, and condolence notes. The series also includes some interfiled general memos on everything from automobiles to dogs, skis, and security.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The Alphabetical Correspondence series consolidates four chronological sets of alphabetical files, arranged by name of correspondent. For the letters A - B only, the files have been integrated and arranged into a single alphabetical run. Beginning with the letter C, and for the rest of the series, the files are arranged alphabetically within each chronological segment, and consequently a correspondent may be found in successive files. The chronological divisions reflect the date ranges of the original record groups: 1962-1976, 1977-1981, 1982-1986, and 1987-1991.
Restricted material, pertaining mainly to living members of the Rockefeller family, has been separated from its place in the alphabetical files and refiled at the end of this series.

scopecontent.p: Folder 168 includes correspondence and background material, 1986-1988, concerning Gunnar Wessman and various New Leaders initiatives.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Friends and Associates series contains named files pertaining to individual friends, relatives, and business associates, spanning the period 1962-1991. Some of the files are true correspondence files, whereas others may cover only a few years' period or may complement additional correspondence in the Alphabetical series. In many cases, the files pertain to memorial arrangements and tributes. Files may also pertain to particular projects undertaken with support from LSR or on his behalf.

The series also includes files for individual Consultants, Employees, and Personnel. Most notably, an extensive series of "Personnel" files for LSR's associate Clayton W. (Wes) Frye helps document his working relationship with LSR, various projects he followed, and his professional and board memberships, from 1973 to the late 1980s.
The files found in the Friends and Associates series come from LSR's papers in the Rockefeller Family general files, record groups 3, 33, 37, and 39.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The Friends and Associates files are arranged in a single alphabetical series by name, followed by categorized files for individual Consultants, Employees, and Personnel.

did.unittitle: Lanier, Jean and Sidney Lanier (Financial Arrangements)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: LSR first met Matousek on his Princeton geology trip in 1930. Files include correspondence with Matousek and family. LSR helped fund visiting professorships for Matousek at Cornell and Berkeley in 1965 and 1971-1972. Includes some description of the 1968 Soviet invasion of Czechoslovakia. Includes 4 photos of Otakar and Bozena Matousek, Milos Matousek, and students, 1975-1982 (in folders 266-268).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Thomas was Director of Horticulture at the Woodstock Inn. File includes 1981 memorandum on horticultural program for Woodstock.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: File contains brief proposals for recreation development projects in southern California and Arizona.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Mail Logs, which were maintained by LSR's office, provide a list of his incoming correspondence arranged by date received. The Logs note the correspondent's name, briefly describe the letter's subject matter and its disposition. Starting in April 1964, the logs also include the date of the letter. The Disposition column indicates the initials of the associate who handled the matter and/or notes action taken in response.

The series also includes one log book for LSR correspondence pertaining to fundraising for Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center. The MSKCC log book primarily notes incoming correspondence, but also includes outgoing acknowledgements.
LSR's mail logs for the period 1953-1961 are found in the LSR papers, RG 2, Office of the Messrs Rockefeller records (FA433), Series 1, box 5, folders 66-67, and box 62.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: File marked "Closed Items," meaning not a restriction, but rather that the items are completed or require no further action.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: File primarily concerns MSKCC's corporate fundraising campaign, and planning for the Sinatra benefit concert for MSKCC in January 1981. File consists of mail log (outgoing and incoming) and some copies of letters sent.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: LSR's chronological files contain copies of LSR's outgoing correspondence, arranged by date. The files consist primarily of LSR's professional correspondence, though they also include personal notes and acknowledgments, and occasional memos to and/or from LSR's associates.
A separate set of chronological files maintained by Carol S. LeBrecht for the period 1976 April - 1978 August has been added at the end of this series.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This set of Chronological Files was maintained by LSR's assistant Carol S. LeBrecht. Contents were originally housed in a prong binder (found in LSR Accession 2008:060).
It is not known how this file compares in contents to the other chronological files for this period.

physdesc.extent: 1 half-size document box, 1 oversized album case.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series consists of two "Special Letters" albums, one of which has been disbound and rehoused in archival folders. Selected letters of recognition and appreciation from prominent figures, friends, and family.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Letters removed from a magnetic photo album, in which they had been arranged and interfiled in chronological order with the letters now found in Lady Bird Johnson file. The current alphabetical arrangement was adopted when the album was disbanded.

Correspondents represented: Albert of Monaco; Tom Brokaw; Warren E. Burger; John G. Burnett; Barbara Bush and George H. W. Bush, 1982, 1985-1986; Rosalynn Carter and Jimmy Carter, 1979, 1983-1984; Mario Cuomo; Malcolm R. Doak; Gerald R. Ford, 1982-1984, 1986; Arthur Godfrey; J. Peter Grace; Hubert H. Humphrey; Luci Johnson; Henry A. Kissinger; Edward Koch; Orin Lehman; Dina Merrill; Joan Mondale; Richard Nixon, 1983-1984; Norman Vincent Peale; Anna Perry-Fiske; Ronald and Nancy Reagan; Lynda Johnson Robb; Happy Rockefeller; Rodman Rockefeller; Alan K. Simpson; Barbara Sinatra; Lewis Thomas.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Restricted. Material in Rockefeller Family collections pertaining to living members of the Rockefeller family is restricted.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Letters removed from a magnetic photo album, in which they had been arranged and interfiled in chronological order with the letters now found in Lady Bird Johnson file. The current alphabetical arrangement was adopted when the album was disbanded.

did.unittitle: Special Letters Album - Lady Bird Johnson

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Letters removed from a magnetic photo album, in which they had been arranged and interfiled in chronological order with the letters now found in the A-Z file. The current alphabetical arrangement was adopted when the album was disbound.

did.physdesc: Post-bound album enclosed in clamshell case, 15.25" x 14.25" x 4.5". Letters tipped in to album pages.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Album of letters from prominent national figures and personal friends. Letters of appreciation for stays at LSR's resorts in the Caribbean (Dorado Beach, Caneel Bay) and Hawaii (Mauna Kea) make up a large proportion of the letters, but recognition of LSR's contributions relating to conservation, outdoor recreation, and the environment, and the fight against cancer, are other signficant themes. "LSR" engraved on album cover.
